literal_eng: Come upstairs and have some figs, get downstairs who told you so!
equivalent_eng: Caught between a rock and a hard place.
darija_ar: طلع تاكول الكرموس, نزل شكون قالها ليك
equivalent: What goes around comes around.
literal: Go up and eat the figs, come down who told you that.

literal_eng: You! The one naked, what do you need? I need a ring made of gold my lord.
equivalent_eng: Putting the cart before the horse.
darija_ar: أش خاصك يا العريان, خاصني خاتم الذهب يا مولاي
equivalent: Mind your own business.
literal: What do you want, you naked one, give me the gold ring, sir.

literal_eng: Don't stick your hand in holes in the ground so that you don't get bitten by snakes.
equivalent_eng: Practice common sense!
darija_ar: ماديرش يدك في غيران باش مايعضوكش الحنوشة
equivalent: Don't put your hand in the snake's hole so it won't bite you.
literal: Don't put your hand in the beehive so they don't sting you!

literal_eng: Don't put your face in bran if you don't want to get pecked by the hens.
equivalent_eng: Practice common sense!
darija_ar: ماديرش راسك في نخالة باش ماينقبوكش الدجاج
equivalent: Don't stick your nose where it doesn't belong.
literal: Don't stick your head in the bran so the chickens don't peck you.

literal_eng: One bitten by a snake will fear a cord.
equivalent_eng: The burnt child dreads the fire.
darija_ar: اللي عضو الحنش كيخاف من الحبل
equivalent: The guilty dog barks the loudest.
literal: The one who stole the goat is afraid of the rope.

literal_eng: He came to help her with her eyeliner and blinded her.
equivalent_eng: Adding insult to injury.
darija_ar: جا يكحلها عماها
equivalent: He came to darken her eyeliner.
literal: He came to fix it up.

literal_eng: If one doesn't have money, their speech is tasteless.
equivalent_eng: Money talks.
darija_ar: اللي ما عندو فلوس كلامو مسوس
equivalent: Empty vessels make the most noise.
literal: Someone who doesn't have money, his words are worthless.

literal_eng: The mice are fighting over the neighbor's yeast.
equivalent_eng: Interfering in someone else's quarrel is like kicking a hornet's nest.
darija_ar: دابزو يا الفيران على خميرة الجيران
equivalent: The pot calling the kettle black.
literal: Jump, you mice, on the neighbors' dough.

literal_eng: Say nice things on your friend around others, chastise him face to face.
equivalent_eng: Praise in public, criticize in private.
darija_ar: امدح صاحبك مع الناس ولومو الراس فالراس
equivalent: Praise your friend in public, criticize him in private.
literal: Praise your friend in front of people and scold him in private.

literal_eng: One eye saw and the other eye did not see.
equivalent_eng: Turning the blind eye.
darija_ar: دير عين شافت وعين ماشافت
equivalent: Turn a blind eye.
literal: One eye sees, the other eye doesn't.

literal_eng: Put a plastic bag on your eye.
equivalent_eng: Turn the blind eye.
darija_ar: دير عين ميكا
equivalent: Turn a blind eye.
literal: Mind your own business.

literal_eng: You don't feel the whip unless you are the one being beaten with it.
equivalent_eng: Walk a mile in my shoes.
darija_ar: ما تيحس بالمزود غير اللي مخبوط به
equivalent: You can't see the forest for the trees.
literal: You only feel the pain of the shoe that pinches you.

literal_eng: Start them off with crayons.
equivalent_eng: breaking it down Barney style.
darija_ar: خصك معاهم الخشيبات
equivalent: Mind your own business.
literal: Mind your own business with them old folks.

literal_eng: The jurist Dahman read the letter for seven days and declared the handwriting was poor.
equivalent_eng: Refusing to admit fault for one's shortcomings.
darija_ar: الفقيه دحمان، قرا البرة سبع ايام، وقاليهم الخط عيان
equivalent: A leopard cannot change its spots.
literal: Al-Faqih Dahman, read the Quran for seven days, and told them the handwriting is clear.

literal_eng: Even the owner of the crown (the king) has needs.
equivalent_eng: It rains on the rich and poor alike.
darija_ar: مول التاج كيحتاج
equivalent: Desperate times call for desperate measures.
literal: The boss needs you.

literal_eng: Think about it 101 times before cutting with the scissors.
equivalent_eng: Measure twice, cut once.
darija_ar: مية تخميمة وتخميمة ولا ضربة بالمقص
equivalent: A shot in the dark.
literal: A hundred guesses and not a single correct one, or a hit with the scissors.

literal_eng: If one wants honey they must endure the sting of bees.
equivalent_eng: Patience and hard work pay off in the end.
darija_ar: اللي بغي لعسل يصبر لقريص النحل
equivalent: If you want honey, be prepared to deal with bees.
literal: Whoever wants honey should be patient with the bees' stings.

literal_eng: A grand funeral for a dead mouse.
equivalent_eng: They're making a mountain out of a molehill.
darija_ar: الگنازة كبيرة والميت فار
equivalent: The funeral is big, but the deceased is a mouse.
literal: The funeral is big and the deceased is a mouse.

literal_eng: If one says the porridge is cold, put his hand in it.
equivalent_eng: Not seeing the forest for the trees.
darija_ar: اللي قال العصيدة باردة، ادير يدو فيها
equivalent: If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.
literal: Whoever said the porridge is cold, let them put their hand in it.

literal_eng: My back can only be scratched with my own fingernails.
equivalent_eng: No one can fix my problem but myself.
darija_ar: ما يحكك اضهري غير ظفري
equivalent: Actions speak louder than words.
literal: Don't talk, just show me your actions.

literal_eng: One said to the other I tricked you and the other said I experienced you (for who you are).
equivalent_eng: fool me once shame on you, fool me twice shame on me.
darija_ar: قالو شمتك، قالو جربتك
equivalent: They said "mock you", they said "tried you".
literal: They said they mocked you, they said they tried you.

literal_eng: Spend time by the babbling brook and not by the silent riverbed.
equivalent_eng: It's always the quiet ones.
darija_ar: دوز على الواد الهرهوري ولا دوز على الواد السكوتي
equivalent: Choose between the devil and the deep blue sea.
literal: Either go to the talkative guy or go to the quiet guy.

literal_eng: If you are raised with something you grow old with it.
equivalent_eng: Old habits die hard.
darija_ar: اللي تربي على شي حاجة كبر عليها
equivalent: You can't teach an old dog new tricks.
literal: Whoever is raised on something will grow accustomed to it.

literal_eng: One who dugs a hole fells into it.
equivalent_eng: They dug their own grave.
darija_ar: لي حفر شي حفرة كيطيح فيها
equivalent: He who digs a pit will fall into it.
literal: Who digs a hole will fall into it.

literal_eng: The people are with the people and the bald guy is combing his hair.
equivalent_eng: He's spinning his wheels.
darija_ar: الناس في الناس والقرع في مشيط الراس
equivalent: People will be people, and a pumpkin will always be a pumpkin.
literal: People are people, and a squash is a squash.

literal_eng: So many elephants have been stung by scorpions.
equivalent_eng: Don't judge a book by its cover.
darija_ar: شحال من الفيل قرصاتوا عقرب
equivalent: The straw that broke the camel's back.
literal: How many times does a scorpion sting an elephant?

literal_eng: The world is a shirt everyone wears for an hour.
equivalent_eng: Life is short.
darija_ar: الدنيا دراعة كل واحد كيلبسها ساعة
equivalent: The world is a sleeve, everyone wears it for a while.
literal: The world is a carousel, everyone wears it for a while.

literal_eng: The beauty is only in the actions.
equivalent_eng: All beauty, no brains.
darija_ar: الزين إلا زين الفعال
equivalent: Actions speak louder than words.
literal: The good is only in doing good.

literal_eng: A day's wedding is a year's planning.
equivalent_eng: Rome wasn't built in a day.
darija_ar: زواج ليلة تدبيره عام
equivalent: A shotgun wedding.
literal: A marriage planned in one night.

literal_eng: The Fqih that we expect his blessing entered the Mosque while wearing his slippers.
equivalent_eng: He talks out of both sides of his mouth.
darija_ar: الفقيه اللي نتسناو براكته ادخل للجامع ببلغته
equivalent: Seeking advice from the wise is like entering a mosque with its own language.
literal: The scholar we are waiting for his blessing, enter the mosque in his language.

literal_eng: Tie your donkey with other donkeys, it will only learn to bray, neigh and from the path he'll stray.
equivalent_eng: You're known by the company you keep.
darija_ar: اربط حمارك مع الحمير، يتعلم الشيق والنهيق وخرجان الطريق
equivalent: Tie your donkey with the donkeys, it will learn the braying and the neighing and will stay on the right path.
literal: Tie your donkey with the other donkeys, he will learn the braying and neighing and get out of the way.

literal_eng: The donkey is hiding but his ears are sticking out in plain sight.
equivalent_eng: You can't hide from your problems.
darija_ar: الحمار مخبي ووذنيه برّا
equivalent: Actions speak louder than words.
literal: The donkey is hiding and its ears are outside.

literal_eng: An oven that goes all around the neighborhood.
equivalent_eng: A powerhouse.
darija_ar: فران وقاد بحومة
equivalent: He talks the talk but doesn't walk the walk.
literal: He's acting all tough and brave.

literal_eng: Flies do not enter a closed mouth.
equivalent_eng: If you can't say something nice, don't say anything at all.
darija_ar: الفم المسدود ما يدخلو دبان
equivalent: A closed mouth catches no flies.
literal: A closed mouth doesn't let flies in.

literal_eng: The world gives to some people and punches others in the stomach.
equivalent_eng: Life deals some people a good hand and others a bad one.
darija_ar: الدنيا شي عطاتو وشي زواتو
equivalent: You win some, you lose some.
literal: Life is a mix of giving and taking.
